Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Algorithms and Verification for Reliable Distributed Cyber-Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are becoming the key enabler in many engineering domains from traffic management to autonomous vehicles. Concurrency, failures, and their interactions with the physical environment make it challenging to wrestle a high level of confidence from such systems. This project develops a reusable middleware service which enables the creation of verified and hence reliable distributed CPS by pushing the state-of-the-art in two directions:
(1) Existing distributed services cannot be practically implemented because of high communication costs incurred in the face of dynamic failures and changes. This project develops a Group Communication Service (GCS) which can be implemented with reasonable resources and which guarantees automatic recovery after failures (stabilization).
(2) Existing verification techniques focus on non-distributed CPS, and in general systems with failures, message delays, etc., are unlikely to be amenable to automated analysis. For applications built with the GCS, the project develops a suite of verification tools that exploit stabilization, compositionality, abstraction-refinement, and delay insensitivity of applications.
These core research tasks will lead to fundamental advances in design and verification of hybrid and distributed systems.

The outcomes of this project are expected to bolster the dependability of emerging applications in autonomous vehicles and factories, and intelligent surveillance systems, while keeping the development costs acceptable through automation. Through industry collaborations, the research outcomes will be translated into engineering practices. The educational component will provide course and lab modules for graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students with the aim of unifying the physical and the computational viewpoints in the systems curriculum. Through active recruitment and mentoring, women and minority students will be prepared for careers in scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The verification problem is about automatically finding bugs in the design of complex engineered systems. Algorithms for verification can also be used to certify that they meet their correctness and safety requirements. Formal verification plays an important role in hardware and software design, but for cyber-physical systems they are yet to make a practical impact. This is in part because the verification pronlem is theoretically undecidable, ane even approximate versions of it are hard to solve because of nonlinear dynamics, asynchrony, and the state space explosion problem.

This project advanced the state of the art in programming and verification of distributed cyber-physical systems by developing new theories, algorithms, and software tools. Among the various approaches developed, the signature concept is an idea called simulation driven verification which combines simulation data together with rigorous analysis of models to find bugs 10-100x faster. And unlike random testing, the technique can also prove safety properties in nonlinear system models that are both important in practice and were largely intractable earlier. We give several examples of the impact these results are having.

In 2012, before the algorithms from the project were available, none of the existing tools were able to verify nonlinear spacecraft control systems.The algorithms coming out of this CAREER project made it possible to verify  these problems directly  (using or tools C2E2 and DryVR) . Specifically in 2016, the AFRL researchers proposed the Automated Rendezvous problem as a challenging control problem to the verification community. DryVR can verify ARPOD, and in fact a fresh (undergraduate student) user is  able to complete the verification task in less than a month. The actual running time for a 4 hour long space mission is about 15 minutes. 

Similarly, in the automotive space, researchers from Toyota posed a verification challenge problem suite involving an engine control system. We were able to automatically verify that the engine meets the required air-fuel ratio range for the simplest version of their benchmark for which our research received the Robert Bosch Best Verification Result Award. 

The PI co-founded a UIUC-based startup company in 2016 to commercialize the simulation-driven verification technology. The company has received $300,000 in funding thus far and is engaged with the DoD and the automotive and aerospace industries, for technology transfer.

The project has supported the research of several outstanding undergraduate, masters, and Phd students over the past several years.  Three of the supported graduate students are women. Taylor Johnson finished his PhD in 2013 and joined University of Texas at Arlington as a Tenure Track Assistant Professor after graduating. In 2016 he moved to Vanderbilt University as an Assistant Professor. Parasara Sridhar Duggirala finished his PhD in 2015 and joined University of Connecticut as a Tenure Track Assistant Professor.  Chuchu Fan has received several prestigious college-level fellowships (MAVIS, Valkenberg, Rambus), was selected for the Heidelberg Laureate Forum, and the Rising Stars in EECS Workshop. Chuchu plans on entering the academic job market in 2018.  Ritwika Ghosh is on track to finish her Phd in 2019. Bolun Qi, Nicole Chan, and YIxiao Lim completed masters degrees and joined industry.
